Getting Started with psychinterpreter

LLM-Powered Interpretation of Psychometric Analyses

Matthias Kloft

2025-11-24

Source: vignettes/articles/01-Getting_Started.qmd

What is psychinterpreter?

The psychinterpreter package automatically interprets psychometric analysis results using Large Language Models (LLMs). LLMs are AI systems (like ChatGPT, Claude, or open-source alternatives) that can understand and generate human-like text. Instead of manually examining complex statistical output and guessing what patterns represent, you get clear, human-readable interpretations and actionable insights.

The package also provides variable labeling functionality to generate short, descriptive labels from variable descriptions, making your data and results more readable.

Currently supported analyses:

  • Factor Analysis - Interpret factor loadings and suggest meaningful factor names

Planned analysis classes:

  • Gaussian Mixture Models - Interpret cluster profiles
  • Item Response Theory (IRT) - Interpret item diagnostics
  • Cognitive Diagnostic Models (CDM) - Interpret Q-matrix patterns

Use this package when you:

  • Have run a psychometric analysis (e.g., factor analysis, clustering)
  • Want automated, data-driven interpretations of your results
  • Need to quickly understand complex patterns in your data

What You Need

Before starting, make sure you have:

  1. Analysis results - from psych::fa(), lavaan::efa(), or similar functions
  2. Variable descriptions - brief explanations of what each variable measures
  3. A language model - we recommend Ollama (free, runs locally, offers cloud-powered models if you have an Ollama account)

Quick Start Example

Here’s a complete workflow for factor analysis using Big Five personality data in just a few lines:

Code
library(psychinterpreter)
library(psych)
library(ollamar)

# 1. Describe your variables
var_info <- data.frame(
  variable = c("A1", "A2", "A3", ...),
  description = c("Am indifferent to others", "Inquire about others", ...)
)

# 2. Generate short labels (optional)
labels <- label_variables(
  variable_info = var_info,
  llm_provider = "ollama",
  llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",
  max_words = 3,
  case = "title"
)

# 3. Run factor analysis
fa_result <- psych::fa(bfi[,1:25], nfactors = 5, rotate = "oblimin")

# 4. Get LLM interpretation
interpretation <- interpret(
  fit_results = fa_result,
  variable_info = var_info,
  llm_provider = "ollama",
  llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud"
)

# 5. View results
print(interpretation)
plot(interpretation)

Step-by-Step Tutorial: Factor Analysis

This tutorial demonstrates the package using factor analysis, but the same workflow applies to other analysis types when they become available.

Let’s walk through a complete example using the Big Five Inventory (BFI) personality data.

Setup

Load the packages we’ll need:

Code
# Install pacman if needed for easy package loading
if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")

# Load packages
pacman::p_load(
  "psychinterpreter",  # This package
  "psych",             # For factor analysis
  "reactable",         # For nice tables
  "dplyr",             # For data manipulation
  "pander"             # package for pretty printing
)

Load and Prepare Data

The BFI dataset contains 25 personality items measuring the Big Five traits.

Code
# Load Big Five Inventory data
data("bfi")
data("bfi.dictionary")

# Keep only the 25 personality items (remove demographics)
bfi_items <- bfi[, 1:25]
bfi_dict <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ]

Here’s what the data looks like:

Code
head(bfi_items, 5) |>
  as.data.frame() |>
  reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE)

And here are the item descriptions:

Code
bfi_dict |>
  select(Item) |>
  as.data.frame() |>
  reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE, defaultPageSize = 10)

Prepare Variable Descriptions

Create a data frame mapping variable names to their descriptions:

Code
variable_info <- data.frame(
  variable = rownames(bfi_dict),
  description = as.character(bfi_dict$Item),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

head(variable_info, 10) |>
  reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE)

Generate Short Variable Labels (Optional)

Before running the analysis, we can use LLMs to generate short, descriptive labels from our variable descriptions. This makes the analysis output and plots more readable:

Code
provider <- "anthropic"
llm <- ellmer::models_anthropic()[1,"id"]
Code
# Generate short labels (1-3 words each)
bfi_labels <- label_variables(
  variable_info = variable_info,
  llm_provider = provider,
  llm_model = llm,
  max_words = 3,        # Keep labels concise
  sep = "_",            # Use underscores between words
  case = "title"        # Title Case format
)

Now replace the original variable names with these short labels:

Code
# Create new variable names combining original names with labels
labels <- paste(
  bfi_labels$labels_formatted$variable,
  bfi_labels$labels_formatted$label,
  sep = "-"
)

# Apply to data and variable_info
colnames(bfi_items) <- labels
variable_info$variable <- labels

# Show updated variable info
head(variable_info, 10) |>
  reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE)

Tip

Label Formatting Options

The label_variables() function offers extensive formatting control:

  • Label types: label_type = "short" (1-3 words), "phrase" (4-7 words), "acronym" (3-5 chars)
  • Case transformations: case = "snake", "camel", "title", "upper", etc.
  • Simplification: remove_articles = TRUE, remove_prepositions = TRUE, abbreviate = TRUE
  • Reformatting: Use reformat_labels() to change formatting without calling the LLM again

See ?label_variables for all options.

Run Factor Analysis

Now perform a standard exploratory factor analysis with 5 factors using the labeled data:

Code
fa_result <- psych::fa(
  bfi_items,  # Now contains labeled variables
  nfactors = 5,
  rotate = "oblimin",  # Oblique rotation
  fm = "ml"            # Maximum likelihood
)

View the factor loadings (now with readable labels):

Code
# Extract and display loadings
loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |>
  as.data.frame()

round(loadings_matrix, 2) |>
  reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE)

Get LLM Interpretation

Now use interpret() to get automatic factor interpretations:

Code
interpretation <- interpret(
  fit_results = fa_result,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  llm_provider = provider,
  llm_model = llm,
  silent = 1  # Will print explicitly below
)

Note

First time using Ollama?

  1. Install Ollama from ollama.com and the ollamar package: install.packages("ollamar")
  2. Pull the model: ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud")
  3. Start the Ollama server before running interpret()

View Results

Print the interpretation report:

Code
print(interpretation)
FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION

Loading cutoff: 0.3
LLM used: anthropic - claude-haiku-4-5-20251001

• Factor 1 (10%): Emotional Instability
• Factor 2 (8.4%): Empathic Concern
• Factor 3 (8.3%): Social Withdrawal
• Factor 4 (8.2%): Conscientious Organization
• Factor 5 (6.6%): Intellectual Engagement

Total variance explained: 41.4%

FACTOR CORRELATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

ML2: ML5 = -.03, ML1 = .23, ML3 = -.21, ML4 = -.01
ML5: ML2 = -.03, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .20, ML4 = .23
ML1: ML2 = .23, ML5 = -.31, ML3 = -.22, ML4 = -.17
ML3: ML2 = -.21, ML5 = .20, ML1 = -.22, ML4 = .20
ML4: ML2 = -.01, ML5 = .23, ML1 = -.17, ML3 = .20

DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Factor 1 (ML2) - Emotional Instability
Number of significant loadings: 5
Variance explained: 9.96%
Factor Correlations: ML5 = -.03, ML1 = .23, ML3 = -.21, ML4 = -.01

Variables:
  1. N1-Anger_Proneness, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .852)
  2. N2-Irritability, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .817)
  3. N3-Mood_Swings, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .665)
  4. N5-Panic_Proneness, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .439)
  5. N4-Depressive_Mood, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .413)

LLM Interpretation:
This factor represents neuroticism and emotional reactivity, capturing the
tendency toward negative affect and emotional dysregulation. Anger proneness
(0.852) and irritability (0.817) are the primary markers, with mood swings
(0.665), panic proneness (0.439), and depressive mood (0.413) providing
secondary indicators. The factor reflects a dispositional vulnerability to
experiencing intense, unstable emotions across various contexts. Individuals
high on this dimension report heightened emotional reactivity, difficulty
managing negative affect, and susceptibility to anxiety and depressive symptoms.
The construct demonstrates strong convergent validity through intercorrelated
negative emotional states.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 2 (ML5) - Empathic Concern
Number of significant loadings: 7
Variance explained: 8.41%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.03, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .20, ML4 = .23

Variables:
  1. A3-Comfort_Others, Know how to comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .668)
  2. A2-Inquire_Well-Being, Inquire about others' well-being. (Positive, Strong,
  .603)
  3. A5-Put_At_Ease, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Strong, .577)
  4. A4-Love_Children, Love children. (Positive, Moderate, .456)
  5. E4-Make_Friends_Easily, Make friends easily. (Positive, Moderate, .362)
  6. A1-Indifferent_To_Others, Am indifferent to the feelings of others.
  (Negative, Moderate, -.360)
  7. E3-Captivate_People, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Moderate,
  .303)

LLM Interpretation:
This factor measures interpersonal warmth and empathic responsiveness,
characterized by genuine concern for others' emotional states and comfort.
Strong loadings on comfort others (0.668), inquire well-being (0.603), and put
at ease (0.577) indicate prosocial and nurturing tendencies. The negative
loading on indifference (−0.360) reinforces orientation toward others' needs.
Secondary loadings on make friends easily (0.362) and captivate people (0.303)
suggest interpersonal facilitation. Notably, love children (0.456) reflects
compassion toward vulnerable populations. This factor represents agreeableness
and empathy, demonstrating convergent validity through theoretically coherent
emotional and social variables.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 3 (ML1) - Social Withdrawal
Number of significant loadings: 7
Variance explained: 8.28%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = .23, ML5 = -.31, ML3 = -.22, ML4 = -.17

Variables:
  1. E2-Difficulty_Approaching, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive,
  Strong, .667)
  2. E1-Quiet, Don't talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .565)
  3. E4-Make_Friends_Easily, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -.527)
  4. N4-Depressive_Mood, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .420)
  5. E5-Take_Charge, Take charge. (Negative, Moderate, -.394)
  6. O4-Reflective, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Moderate, .357)
  7. E3-Captivate_People, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Moderate,
  -.341)

LLM Interpretation:
This factor captures introversion and social inhibition, defined by difficulty
in interpersonal engagement and avoidance of social interaction. Difficulty
approaching others (0.667) and quietness (0.565) are primary indicators of
social hesitance, with strong negative loadings on social facilitation: make
friends easily (−0.527), take charge (−0.394), and captivate people (−0.341).
Secondary loadings on depressive mood (0.420) and reflective (0.357) suggest
accompanying introspection or withdrawal-related mood. This factor represents
the introverted end of extraversion, distinct from social competence. The
pattern demonstrates discriminant validity from empathy, measuring behavioral
social inhibition rather than emotional warmth.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 4 (ML3) - Conscientious Organization
Number of significant loadings: 5
Variance explained: 8.19%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.21, ML5 = .20, ML1 = -.22, ML4 = .20

Variables:
  1. C4-Half-Way_Effort, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong,
  -.643)
  2. C2-Perfectionist, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong,
  .638)
  3. C5-Waste_Time, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -.570)
  4. C3-Plan-Oriented, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .564)
  5. C1-Exacting_Work, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .532)

LLM Interpretation:
This factor reflects conscientiousness and organized goal-directedness through
achievement-oriented and systematic behaviors. Perfectionism (0.638), exacting
work standards (0.532), and plan-oriented approaches (0.564) represent the core
construct. Notably, the strong negative loadings on half-way effort (−0.643) and
wasting time (−0.570) demonstrate disciplined commitment and efficiency.
Secondary positive loading on take charge (0.274) suggests assertive
implementation of standards. The factor captures meticulous, organized
personality traits driving task completion and quality outcomes. Convergent
validity is demonstrated through theoretically consistent work ethic and
discipline indicators, complementing but remaining distinct from other
personality dimensions.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 5 (ML4) - Intellectual Engagement
Number of significant loadings: 6
Variance explained: 6.57%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.01, ML5 = .23, ML1 = -.17, ML3 = .20

Variables:
  1. O3-Deep_Conversation, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (Positive,
  Strong, .633)
  2. O1-Full_Of_Ideas, Am full of ideas. (Positive, Strong, .534)
  3. O5-Avoid_Deep_Probing, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Negative,
  Strong, -.522)
  4. O2-Avoid_Complex_Reading, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative,
  Moderate, -.441)
  5. O4-Reflective, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Moderate, .379)
  6. E3-Captivate_People, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Moderate,
  .315)

LLM Interpretation:
This factor represents openness to experience and cognitive curiosity,
emphasizing intellectual sophistication and reflective thinking. Deep
conversation (0.633) and full of ideas (0.534) indicate abstract thinking and
intellectual engagement. Notably, the strong negative loadings on avoid complex
reading (−0.441) and avoid deep probing (−0.522) demonstrate intellectual
approach rather than avoidance. Secondary loadings on reflective (0.379) and
captivate people (0.315) suggest analytical depth and communicative ability.
This factor captures openness-related intellectual curiosity and preference for
complex cognitive tasks. The construct demonstrates discriminant validity from
other factors, uniquely measuring cognitive engagement and intellectual
disposition.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

CROSS-LOADING VARIABLES
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Variables loading on multiple factors (>= 0.3):
- E3-Captivate_People: ML5 (.303), ML1 (-.341), ML4 (.315)
- E4-Make_Friends_Easily: ML5 (.362), ML1 (-.527)
- N4-Depressive_Mood: ML2 (.413), ML1 (.420)
- O4-Reflective: ML1 (.357), ML4 (.379)

The output shows: - Suggested factor names - Which variables load on each factor - A brief interpretation of what the factor represents

View suggested factor names:

Code
suggested_names <- interpretation$suggested_names |>
  unlist()

data.frame(Suggested_Factor_Name = suggested_names) |>
  reactable(striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, bordered = TRUE, compact = TRUE)

Visualize Factor Structure

Create a visual representation of the factor loadings:

Code
plot(interpretation, cutoff = 0.3)

This plot shows which variables load strongly on each factor, making it easy to see the factor structure at a glance.

Export Results

Save your interpretation to a file:

Code
# Export as markdown
export_interpretation(
  interpretation,
  format = "md",
  file = "bfi_interpretation"
)

# Export as plain text
export_interpretation(
  interpretation,
  format = "txt",
  file = "bfi_interpretation"
)

Customizing Your Interpretation

You can control several aspects of the interpretation:

Key parameters:

  • cutoff: Threshold for displaying results (e.g., minimum loading for FA)
  • hide_low_loadings: Whether to hide loadings below the cutoff from the LLM
  • word_limit: Control how verbose the LLM interpretations are
  • output_format: Choose between plain text or markdown formatting
  • heading_level: Heading level to start the report with.
Code
interpretation <- interpret(
  fit_results = fa_result,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  llm_provider = provider,
  llm_model = llm,

  cutoff = 0.4,              # Threshold for including results (default: 0.3)
  hide_low_loadings = TRUE,  # hide low loadings below cutoff from the LLM
  word_limit = 30,          # Max words per interpretation (default: 150)
  output_format = "markdown",# Output format: "text" or "markdown"
  heading_level = 3,         # set heading level for markdown output
)

Slightly weaker affection toward children suggests the factor emphasizes demonstrated empathic behavior over general fondness.

  • O4-Reflective (highest: ML4 = .379)

Common Questions

Q: What if the LLM interpretation seems wrong?

The LLM bases interpretations on your variable descriptions and statistical results. You can:

  • Provide better, more descriptive variable descriptions
  • Use a bigger LLM. Small models may struggle with the task and structured output requirements.
  • Adjust the cutoff and hide_low_loadings parameters to change which results are included
  • Add context with the additional_info parameter

Q: Can I use different LLMs?

Yes! The package supports all providers supported by the ellmer package, for example:

  • Ollama (local, free): llm_provider = "ollama"
  • OpenAI (API key required): llm_provider = "openai"
  • Anthropic Claude (API key required): llm_provider = "anthropic"

Q: How do I set API keys for OpenAI or Anthropic?

Code
# Add to your .Renviron file:
Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "your-key-here")
Sys.setenv(ANTHROPIC_API_KEY = "your-key-here")

Also refer to the documentation of the ellmer https://ellmer.tidyverse.org/ package.

Session Info

Code
pander::pander(sessionInfo())

R version 4.5.2 (2025-10-31 ucrt)

Platform: x86_64-w64-mingw32/x64

locale: LC_COLLATE=German_Germany.utf8, LC_CTYPE=German_Germany.utf8, LC_MONETARY=German_Germany.utf8, LC_NUMERIC=C and LC_TIME=German_Germany.utf8

attached base packages: stats, graphics, grDevices, utils, datasets, methods and base
